content: The "Economic Freedom Act of 2010" allows for a zero percent capital gains rate for individuals and corporations. The "Economic Freedom Act of 2010" includes a provision for a zero percent capital gains rate for individuals, with amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Economic Freedom Act of 2010" includes a provision for a zero percent capital gains rate for individuals and corporations, with amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act repeals the sunset of reduction in capital gains rates for individuals and imposes a tax on corporations with net capital gains. The net capital gain is taxed at different rates: 0 percent for adjusted net capital gain or taxable income, 25 percent for unrecaptured section 1250 gain, and 28 percent for taxable income exceeding certain thresholds. The terms 'adjusted net capital gain' and 'unrecaptured section 1250 gain' are defined in section 1(h). Net capital gain is taxed at different rates, with a maximum rate for corporations specified in section 55(b). The tax rates for net capital gain are computed as if this paragraph had not been enacted, reduced by the net capital gain, plus amendments to various sections of the tax code. The tax rates for net capital gain are amended to be 0 percent, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2009. The amendments also apply to dispositions and distributions after the date of the enactment of this Act. The corporate income tax rates are reduced. The corporate income tax rates are reduced to 12.5 percent of taxable income. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code to reflect this change. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including changes to tax rates and specific sections like 1375(a), 860E, 860K, 1446(b), 7874(e), 904(b), 962, and 1201(a). Amendments are made to Section 1561(a) of the Internal Revenue Code, including redesignating paragraphs and adjusting percentages. Amendments are made to Section 1561(a) of the Internal Revenue Code, including redesignating paragraphs and adjusting percentages. Subsection (b) of section 1561 is amended for certain short taxable years within a controlled group of corporations. The amendments made by this section have an effective date. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2009. SEC. 4. Estate tax repeal made permanent. Section 901 of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 shall not apply to title V of such Act. SEC. 5. Election to expense business assets. Section 179 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow the election to expense certain depreciable business assets. A taxpayer can elect to treat the cost of certain tangible property or computer software as an expense, not a capital cost, allowing for a deduction in the year the property is placed in service. This applies to section 1245 or 1250 property. The term 'purchase' for section 1250 property means acquiring property for use in a trade or business, excluding certain types of property like air conditioning or heating units. The acquisition must not be from a person whose relationship would disallow losses under specific sections. The cost of property for tax purposes excludes the basis determined by the basis of other property held by the person acquiring it. The section defines a controlled group and specifies that no credit is allowed under section 38 if a deduction is allowed under subsection (a). Regulations will provide for recapturing deductions for property not used predominantly in a trade or business. An election is also mentioned in the section. The section discusses an election that specifies property items for a taxable year and is irrevocable without the Secretary's consent. The amendment applies to property placed in service after the enactment date of the Act. SEC. 6. PAYROLL TAX DECREASE FOR 2010. Employees and employers will receive a reduction in tax rates for wages received and paid during the calendar year 2010. The tax rate for wages will be reduced from 6.2 percent to 3.1 percent for employees and from 1.45 percent to 0.725 percent for employers. In 2010, tax rates for wages will be reduced for employees and employers. For employees, the rate will decrease from 6.2 percent to 3.1 percent, and for employers, it will decrease from 1.45 percent to 0.725 percent. These changes will apply to remuneration paid after December 31, 2009. SEC. 7. RESCISSION AND REPEAL IN ARRA. Unobligated balances from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 are rescinded, and certain subtitles and titles are repealed. SEC. 8. TERMINATION OF TARP AUTHORITY. The TARP authority under the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 will terminate upon the enactment of the Economic Freedom Act of 2010. SEC. 9. REQUIRING THE SALE OF STOCK AND WARRANTS RECEIVED UNDER TARP. SEC. 9. REQUIRING THE SALE OF STOCK AND WARRANTS RECEIVED UNDER TARP. The Secretary of the Treasury must sell all stock and warrants acquired under the Troubled Asset Relief Program within one year of the enactment of this Act.
